habitat_description:
Southwest:
The Chihuahuan pocket mouse is associated with soft, sparsely vegetated, sandy alluvial soils along streams, desert washes, and valley bottoms. Because this species utilizes underground burrows, rocky or gravelly and otherwise impermeable soils are a limiting factore in its distribution (Davis and Schmidly 1994; Findley et al. 1975; Jones and Manning 1991; Yancey 1997). In the Big Bend area, C. eremicus has been found in large numbers within loose sands of the Rio Grande river floodplains where the dominant vegetation is Baccharis and mesquite or brushy draws with hard packed river silts (Schmidly 2004). Other occupied habitats include riparian areas (Yancey 1997), desert scrublands and grasslands dominated by vegetation species such as catclaw (Acacia), cresotebush (Larrea), mesquite (Prosopis), and tasajillo (Opuntia—Schmidly 1977); as well as grasses such as Bouteloua gracilis, Muhlenbergia arenacea, Oryzopsis hymenoides, Sporobolous airoides, S. cryptandrus, and S. flexuosus), Tiquilia hispidissima, and Yucca elata (Root et al. 1999; Mantooth and Best 2005). C. eremicus also is the most common species on dunes at White Sands National Monument in southern New Mexico (Root et al. 1999; Mantooth and Best 2005), and occurs in plains-mesa sand scrub habitats (Frey and Yates 1996; Mantooh and Best 2005). This species burrows at the base of bushy and scrubby plants feeding on seeds of mesquite, creosote, and broomweed (Schmidly 2004).
